citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Female Italian greyhound (#93300320376795, DOB 09-10-2020, "Destiny") has poor dental health. Over half the surface
of the upper left canine tooth is covered in a thick dark brown material. The front tooth located directly next to this canine
tooth is loose and moved easily when gently manipulated by the inspector. Nearly the entire surface of this loose tooth is
coated in a thick buildup of dark brown and grey colored material. The upper left gums are slightly reddened and have
receded away from both of these teeth.
Approximately, half the surface of the upper right canine tooth is coated in dark brown organic material. The front tooth
located directly next to this canine tooth has nearly the entire surface covered in a thick buildup of brown and grey colored
material. The gums are slightly reddened and have receded away from the front tooth. The entire surface of the remaining
upper right cheek tooth is covered in a buildup of dark brown material. The condition of the dog's teeth has not been
identified by the facility, and no treatment has been provided or planned.
Poor dental health can cause pain and discomfort and lead to further health issues.
Each dealer must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee
must have this dog evaluated by a veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an effective treatment plan. The
licensee must also ensure that each dog receives adequate veterinary care at all times.
Correction date: By the time of the exit interview on January 22, 2026, the dog had already received treatment from a
veterinarian.

The facility is not having each dog physically examined by the attending veterinarian at least once every 12 months.
During the inspection, a female Italian greyhound was identified by the inspector as having poor dental health. Review of
the dog's medical records revealed she had received an examination from the attending veterinarian in April 2024 but has
not been physically examined by the attending veterinarian since then. The facility's Program of Veterinary Care (PVC)
states the dogs will receive a physical examination from the attending veterinarian yearly. Failure to have each dog
examined by the attending veterinarian may cause health issues to go unnoticed which could allow these issues to
worsen before they are finally identified.
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care which must include a complete physical examination
from head to tail of each dog by the attending veterinarian no less than once every 12 months. The licensee must ensure
that each dog is physically examined by the attending veterinarian no less than every 12 months. The licensee must also
ensure that all procedures and plans documented in the PVC are followed at all times.
Correction date: Beginning January 22, 2026, the licensee must ensure each dog is examined at least once every 12
months.

The facility is not following the dental plan documented in the Program of Veterinary Care (PVC). The dental plan
documented in the PVC says that dentals will be done yearly. Additionally, the licensee stated that the attending
veterinarian has also approved the use of Tylan powder to aid in dental health which is added to their food every 3 days.
During the inspection one female Italian greyhound was identified with poor dental health and she last dental cleaning she
received in April 2024. Failure to follow the dental plan could result in poor dental health which can cause pain and
discomfort to the animals as well as lead to further health issues.
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that contains a preventative care and treatment plan to
maintain clean and healthy teeth. The licensee must follow the dental plan documented in the PVC and ensure the plan is
effective at maintaining clean and healthy teeth.
Correction date: January 22, 2026
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Female Italian greyhound (#93300320376795, DOB 09-10-2020, "Destiny") has poor dental health. Over half the surface 
of the upper left canine tooth is covered in a thick dark brown material. The front tooth located directly next to this canine 
tooth is loose and moved easily when gently manipulated by the inspector. Nearly the entire surface of this loose tooth is 
coated in a thick buildup of dark brown and grey colored material. The upper left gums are slightly reddened and have 
receded away from both of these teeth.  
 
Approximately, half the surface of the upper right canine tooth is coated in dark brown organic material. The front tooth 
located directly next to this canine tooth has nearly the entire surface covered in a thick buildup of brown and grey colored 
material. The gums are slightly reddened and have receded away from the front tooth. The entire surface of the remaining 
upper right cheek tooth is covered in a buildup of dark brown material. The condition of the dog's teeth has not been 
identified by the facility, and no treatment has been provided or planned.  
 
Poor dental health can cause pain and discomfort and lead to further health issues. 
 
Each dealer must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee 
must have this dog evaluated by a veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an effective treatment plan. The 
licensee must also ensure that each dog receives adequate veterinary care at all times. 
 
Correction date: By the time of the exit interview on January 22, 2026, the dog had already received treatment from a 
veterinarian. 
3.13(a)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not having each dog physically examined by the attending veterinarian at least once every 12 months. 
During the inspection, a female Italian greyhound was identified by the inspector as having poor dental health. Review of 
the dog's medical records revealed she had received an examination from the attending veterinarian in April 2024 but has 
not been physically examined by the attending veterinarian since then. The facility's Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) 
states the dogs will receive a physical examination from the attending veterinarian yearly. Failure to have each dog 
examined by the attending veterinarian may cause health issues to go unnoticed which could allow these issues to

worsen before they are finally identified. 
 
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care which must include a complete physical examination 
from head to tail of each dog by the attending veterinarian no less than once every 12 months. The licensee must ensure 
that each dog is physically examined by the attending veterinarian no less than every 12 months. The licensee must also 
ensure that all procedures and plans documented in the PVC are followed at all times. 
 
Correction date: Beginning January 22, 2026, the licensee must ensure each dog is examined at least once every 12 
months. 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not following the dental plan documented in the Program of Veterinary Care (PVC). The dental plan 
documented in the PVC says that dentals will be done yearly. Additionally, the licensee stated that the attending 
veterinarian has also approved the use of Tylan powder to aid in dental health which is added to their food every 3 days. 
During the inspection one female Italian greyhound was identified with poor dental health and she last dental cleaning she 
received in April 2024. Failure to follow the dental plan could result in poor dental health which can cause pain and 
discomfort to the animals as well as lead to further health issues. 
 
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that contains a preventative care and treatment plan to 
maintain clean and healthy teeth. The licensee must follow the dental plan documented in the PVC and ensure the plan is 
effective at maintaining clean and healthy teeth.  
 
Correction date: January 22, 2026 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
